content.question: In an experiment, a spring is placed between object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has twice the mass of object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, which has mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The two objects are pushed together until the spring is at its maximum compression, as shown in the figure. The objects are released from rest, and data are collected for the speed of each object immediately after the spring is no longer compressed. However, the graph does not indicate which object corresponds to a given velocity, and the positive direction is not indicated. Which of the following correctly describes the velocities of object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> after the collision?

choices.label: Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="4 meters per seconds" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext> </mtext><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="negative 2 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> after the spring is no longer compressed.

Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="negative 2 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="4 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>4</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> after the spring is no longer compressed.
Either object can have either speed because the conservation of momentum will still be maintained.
Not enough information is given to match the objects to a specific speed after the spring is no longer compressed.

content.answer: Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="negative 2 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> travels at <math alttext="4 meters per second" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>4</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> after the spring is no longer compressed.

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
